question: The lunch looked charming, and as she surveyed it, she sincerely hoped it would taste well, and that the borrowed [MASK], china, and silver would get safely home again.
source_info: Little Women by Alcott, Louisa M. (Louisa May)
title: Little Women
prev_sentence: The parlor struck her as looking uncommonly shabby, but without stopping to sigh for what she had not, she skillfully made the best of what she had, arranging chairs over the worn places in the carpet, covering stains on the walls with homemade statuary, which gave an artistic air to the room, as did the lovely vases of flowers Jo scattered about.
next_sentence: The carriages were promised, Meg and Mother were all ready to do the honors, Beth was able to help Hannah behind the scenes, Jo had engaged to be as lively and amiable as an absent mind, and aching head, and a very decided disapproval of everybody and everything would allow, and as she wearily dressed, Amy cheered herself with anticipations of the happy moment when, lunch safely over, she should drive away with her friends for an afternoon of artistic delights, for the 'cherry bounce' and the broken bridge were her strong points.

question: Feeling that the neighbors were interested in her movements, she wished to efface the memory of yesterday's failure by a grand success today, so she ordered the 'cherry [MASK]', and drove away in state to meet and escort her guests to the banquet.
source_info: Little Women by Alcott, Louisa M. (Louisa May)
title: Little Women
prev_sentence: She did not mention this meeting at home (though she discovered that, thanks to the upset, her new dress was much damaged by the rivulets of dressing that meandered down the skirt), but went through with the preparations which now seemed more irksome than before, and at twelve o'clock all was ready again.
next_sentence: "There's the rumble, they're coming!

question: Jo wouldn't love him, but he might make her [MASK] and admire him by doing something which should prove that a girl's 'No' had not spoiled his life.

title: Little Women

question: Like most young scribblers, she went abroad for her [MASK] and scenery, and banditti, counts, gypsies, nuns, and duchesses appeared upon her stage, and played their parts with as much accuracy and spirit as could be expected.
source_info: Little Women by Alcott, Louisa M. (Louisa May)
title: Little Women
prev_sentence: Following Mr. Dashwood's directions, and making Mrs. Northbury her model, Jo rashly took a plunge into the frothy sea of sensational literature, but thanks to the life preserver thrown her by a friend, she came up again not much the worse for her ducking.
next_sentence: Her readers were not particular about such trifles as grammar, punctuation, and probability, and Mr. Dashwood graciously permitted her to fill his columns at the lowest prices, not thinking it necessary to tell her that the real cause of his hospitality was the fact that one of his hacks, on being offered higher wages, had basely left him in the lurch.

question: The lobster was instantly surrounded by a halo of pleasing reminiscences, and curiosity about 'the charming young ladies' diverted his mind from the comical [MASK].

title: Little Women

question: What put it into your [MASK], little mother? ''

title: Little Women
prev_sentence: You have been shut up so long, it will do you no end of good, and I shall enjoy it, of all things.
next_sentence: "Well, I had a talk with Marmee the other day, and told her how nervous and cross and out of sorts I felt, and she said I needed change and less care, so Hannah is to help me with the children, and I'm to see to things about the house more, and now and then have a little fun, just to keep me from getting to be a fidgety, broken-down old woman before my time.

question: Sacred moments, when heart talked to heart in the silence of the night, turning [MASK] to a blessing, which chastened grief and strengthened love.
source_info: Little Women by Alcott, Louisa M. (Louisa May)
title: Little Women
prev_sentence: For, as quick to hear her sobbing as she had been to hear her sister's faintest whisper, her mother came to comfort her, not with words only, but the patient tenderness that soothes by a touch, tears that were mute reminders of a greater grief than Jo's, and broken whispers, more eloquent than prayers, because hopeful resignation went hand-in-hand with natural sorrow.
next_sentence: Feeling this, Jo's burden seemed easier to bear, duty grew sweeter, and life looked more endurable, seen from the safe shelter of her mother's arms.

question: Want of breath brought the [MASK] ball to a close, and then people began to go.
source_info: Little Women by Alcott, Louisa M. (Louisa May)
title: Little Women
prev_sentence: But the crowning joke was Mr. Laurence and Aunt March, for when the stately old gentleman chasseed solemnly up to the old lady, she just tucked her cane under her arm, and hopped briskly away to join hands with the rest and dance about the bridal pair, while the young folks pervaded the garden like butterflies on a midsummer day.
next_sentence: "I wish you well, my dear, I heartily wish you well, but I think you'll be sorry for it," said Aunt March to Meg, adding to the bridegroom, as he led her to the carriage, "You've got a treasure, young man, see that you deserve it."

question: When he looked about him for another and a less intractable damsel to immortalize in [MASK], memory produced one with the most obliging readiness.

title: Little Women
prev_sentence: and a clutch at his hair, as became a distracted composer.
next_sentence: This phantom wore many faces, but it always had golden hair, was enveloped in a diaphanous cloud, and floated airily before his mind's eye in a pleasing chaos of roses, peacocks, white ponies, and blue ribbons.

question: Gentlemen, which means boys, be courteous to the old maids, no matter how poor and plain and prim, for the only chivalry worth having is that which is the readiest to pay deference to the old, protect the feeble, and serve [MASK], regardless of rank, age, or color.
source_info: Little Women by Alcott, Louisa M. (Louisa May)
title: Little Women
prev_sentence: That rosy cheeks don't last forever, that silver threads will come in the bonnie brown hair, and that, by-and-by, kindness and respect will be as sweet as love and admiration now.
next_sentence: Just recollect the good aunts who have not only lectured and fussed, but nursed and petted, too often without thanks, the scrapes they have helped you out of, the tips they have given you from their small store, the stitches the patient old fingers have set for you, the steps the willing old feet have taken, and gratefully pay the dear old ladies the little attentions that women love to receive as long as they live.

question: The [MASK] orchard wore its holiday attire.

title: Little Women

question: He was in one of his moods, for the day had been both unprofitable and unsatisfactory, and he was wishing he could [MASK] it over again.
source_info: Little Women by Alcott, Louisa M. (Louisa May)
title: Little Women
prev_sentence: CHAPTER THIRTEEN  CASTLES IN THE AIR  Laurie lay luxuriously swinging to and fro in his hammock one warm September afternoon, wondering what his neighbors were about, but too lazy to go and find out.
next_sentence: The hot weather made him indolent, and he had shirked his studies, tried Mr. Brooke's patience to the utmost, displeased his grandfather by practicing half the afternoon, frightened the maidservants half out of their wits by mischievously hinting that one of his dogs was going mad, and, after high words with the stableman about some fancied neglect of his horse, he had flung himself into his hammock to fume over the stupidity of the world in general, till the peace of the lovely day quieted him in spite of himself.

question: Not a very splendid show, but there was a great deal of love done up in the few little bundles, and the tall vase of red roses, white [MASK], and trailing vines, which stood in the middle, gave quite an elegant air to the table.
source_info: Little Women by Alcott, Louisa M. (Louisa May)
title: Little Women
prev_sentence: "That's loving our neighbor better than ourselves, and I like it," said Meg, as they set out their presents while their mother was upstairs collecting clothes for the poor Hummels.

question: Let the boys be boys, the longer the better, and let the young men [MASK] their wild oats if they must.
source_info: Little Women by Alcott, Louisa M. (Louisa May)
title: Little Women
prev_sentence: Women work a good many miracles, and I have a persuasion that they may perform even that of raising the standard of manhood by refusing to echo such sayings.
next_sentence: But mothers, sisters, and friends may help to make the crop a small one, and keep many tares from spoiling the harvest, by believing, and showing that they believe, in the possibility of loyalty to the virtues which make men manliest in good women's eyes.

question: She felt comforted at once by the sympathy and confidence [MASK] her.

title: Little Women
prev_sentence: The patience and the humility of the face she loved so well was a better lesson to Jo than the wisest lecture, the sharpest reproof.

title: Little Women
